title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – The roar in the Target Center was not for the home team, but for a visiting force of nature named Gary Payton. In a virtuoso performance that will be etched into the annals of franchise history, Payton put the Seattle SuperSonics on his back and carried them to a bruising 108-99 victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

Payton was simply unplayable, orchestrating the game with a maestro's touch and a scorer's ruthlessness. He erupted for a career-high and franchise-record 47 points, slicing through the Timberwolves' defense at will. But "The Glove" was more than just a scorer; he was a complete basketball savant, dishing out 9 assists and snatching 4 steals, leaving the Minnesota backcourt utterly bewildered.

While Payton authored the masterpiece, he received crucial support. Detlef Schrempf provided a steadying hand with 19 points, and Vin Baker battled inside for a hard-earned 17 points and 13 rebounds. For the Timberwolves, the stellar efforts of Kevin Garnett, who posted 23 points and 14 rebounds, and Stephon Marbury's 25 points were ultimately rendered secondary footnotes to Payton's historic night.

Every Minnesota run was met with a cold, decisive response from Payton—a pull-up jumper, a steal and run-out, or a perfectly timed dish to a teammate. This was more than a win; it was a declaration. On this night, Gary Payton wasn't just the best player on the floor; he was an unstoppable force, delivering a performance for the ages and a signature victory for the Sonics.
